definition: Protective or functional outer structures that form the external surface of animal bodies or body parts.

positive_examples: The turtle withdrew into its hard shell when threatened.
Bird feathers provide insulation and enable flight.
The horse's hooves clattered on the cobblestone street.
Armadillo shells are made of overlapping bony plates.
Peacock feathers displayed brilliant iridescent colors.
The blacksmith fitted iron shoes to protect the horse's hooves.
negative_examples: The doctor examined the patient's internal organs.
She felt the bone beneath the skin on her arm.
The muscle tissue contracted when stimulated.
Blood vessels carried oxygen throughout the body.
The nervous system controls bodily functions.
Cartilage cushions the joints between bones.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: InternalOrgans, SkeletalStructure, MuscularSystem, CirculatorySystem

opposite_reasoning: InternalOrgans provides the strongest semantic opposition to ExternalCoverings based on clear spatial complementarity (external surface vs internal functional structures). This opposition is: (1) Semantically robust - they are mutually exclusive anatomical categories with clear spatial boundaries, (2) Conceptually coherent - both are structural/functional body components at similar ontological levels, (3) Likely available - InternalOrgans is a common concept in both WordNet and SUMO ontologies, (4) Useful for Fisher-LDA - creates a clear axis from surface/protective structures to core/functional organs. While this opposition has limited direct relevance to AI safety concerns like deception detection, it provides a clean geometric opposition for the concept space that could be useful for distinguishing surface-level vs deep-level features in other contexts.
